```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library("MASS")
library("dplyr")
library("ggplot2")
library("grid")
library("stringr")
library("reshape2")
library("PerformanceAnalytics")


irs_2011_2015 <- readRDS('../../r-objects/irs_2011_2015.rds')
education_df_plus_3 <- readRDS('../../r-objects/education_df_plus_3.rds')
zip_codes_df <- readRDS('../../r-objects/zip_irs_education_df.rds')
demo_act <- readRDS('../../r-objects/zip_irs_education_df.rds')[, c("Pct_Black", "Pct_Hispanic", "ACT_Composite", "county", "income_per_tax_return")]

```

```{r, echo=FALSE}
df_sort <- irs_2011_2015 %>% 
  filter(income_per_tax_return >= 8) %>% 
  select(county, year, income_per_tax_return)

```

<div class="row question-row">
  <blockquote class="blockquote">
    Income Distribution Amongst TN Counties (2011-2015)
  </blockquote>
<div class="col-md-7">
```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.height=5, fig.width=4}

h <- hist(df_sort$income_per_tax_return, breaks=10, plot=FALSE)
cuts <- cut(h$breaks, c(-Inf, 9, 19, 23, 25, Inf))
plot(
  h, 
  col=c('#062F4F', '#6D7993', '#B82601', '#6D7993', '#B82601')[cuts],
  main = '',
  xlab = 'Avg Income Per Tax Return * 1000',
  ylab = 'County Frequency'
)

```
</div>
<div class="col-md-5 description" style="margin-top: 5em;">
  <p>Plotting a histogram of the average income per tax returns for these years shows us that the majority of households fall between $8000 and $14000.</p>
  <p>The lowest county being <em>Madison County</em> in 2011, and the highest with <em>Williamson County</em> in 2015.<em></p>
  <p>According to the Census ACS 1-year survey, the median household income for Tennessee was $48,547 in 2016, the latest figures available. Compared to the median US household income, Tennessee median household income is $9,070 lower.</p>
</div>
</div>

```{r irs_2011_2015, echo = FALSE}
df_sort <- irs_2011_2015 %>% 
  filter(income_per_tax_return >= 8) %>%

  )

df_sort %>%
```

  </div>

</div>




```{r, echo=FALSE}
ggplot_num_returns <- function(df, range, y.label="", point=FALSE) {
  df_sort_1 <- irs_2011_2015 %>% 
    dplyr::filter(sum_total_income_returns >= range) %>% 
    dplyr::select(
      county, year, sum_total_income_returns
    )
  
  p <- df_sort_1 %>% 
    ggplot(
      aes(
        x = year,
        y = sum_total_income_returns, 
        group = county,
        color = county
      )
    ) + 
    geom_line(size = 1.5) + 
    labs(y = y.label, x = "") +
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(
        face = 'bold', 
        size = 14
      )
    ) +
    theme(axis.text.y = element_text(
        face = 'bold', 
        size = 14
      )
    ) +
    theme(axis.title.y = element_text(
        size = 20
      )
    ) +
    scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
    scale_color_hue(l = 60, c = 50)
  
  if (point) {
    p + 
      geom_point() +
      geom_label(
        aes(label=sum_total_income_returns), 
        hjust = 0, 
        vjust = 0,
        nudge_x = -.5,
        nudge_y = .2
      )
  } else {
    p
  }
}

```

```{r, echo=FALSE}
create_hist <- function(df, col.name, col.breaks, col.colors, main, y.lab='') {
  h <- hist(df[[col.name]], breaks=10, plot=FALSE)
  cuts <- cut(h$breaks, col.breaks)
  plot(
    h, 
    col=col.colors[cuts],
    main = main,
    ylab = y.lab,
    xlab = ''
  )
}
```


```{r, echo=FALSE}
create_hist <- function(df, col.name, col.breaks, col.colors, main, y.lab='') {
  h <- hist(df[[col.name]], breaks=10, plot=FALSE)
  cuts <- cut(h$breaks, col.breaks)
  plot(
    h, 
    col=col.colors[cuts],
    main = '',
    ylab = y.lab,
    xlab = ''
  )
}
```


<div class="row question-row">
  <blockquote class="blockquote">
    Overall Education Pct Regarding Student 
    Graduation, Dropout, and Suspension
  </blockquote>
  <div class="col-md-12">
```{r, echo=FALSE}
par(mfrow=c(1, 3))
education_df_plus_3 %>% 
  create_hist('Graduation', c(-Inf, 81, 91, 95, Inf), c('#B82601', '#6D7993', '#062F4F', '#6D7993'), 'Graduation', y.lab = 'County Frequency')

education_df_plus_3 %>% 
  create_hist('Dropout', c(-Inf, 1, 3, 4, 11, 12, 14, Inf), c('#6D7993', '#062F4F', '#6D7993', '#6D7993', '#B82601', '#6D7993', '#B82601'), 'Dropout')

education_df_plus_3 %>% 
  create_hist('Pct_Suspended', c(-Inf, 1, 6, 11, 13, Inf), c('#062F4F', '#6D7993', '#B82601', '#6D7993', '#B82601'), 'Pct Suspended')

```
  </div>
<div class="row description">
  <p>Now we get into the education data. Plotting these graphs provide some insight with regards to the highest and lowest counties.</p>
  
* Graduation rate is highest in Meigs, lowest in <strong><em>Shelby</em></strong>.
* Dropout rate is highest in <strong><em>Shelby</em></strong> county, while kids are studious in Pickett and Meigs counties.
* Teachers seem to be <em>very</em> strict in <strong><em>Shelby</em></strong> county, since it holds the highest student suspension rate.

</div>
</div>




<div class="row question-row">
  <blockquote class="blockquote">
    Overall Education Pct Regarding Student 
    ACT Scores, Math, Science, and Literature

```{r, echo=FALSE}

education_df_plus_3 %>% 
  create_hist('ACT_Composite', c(-Inf, 17, 18, 20, Inf), c('#6D7993', '#062F4F', '#6D7993', '#B82601'), 'ACT_Composite', y.lab = 'County Frequency')

education_df_plus_3 %>% 
  create_hist('mean_math', c(-Inf, 19, 39, 69, 79, 89, Inf), c('#6D7993', '#B82601', '#6D7993', '#062F4F', '#6D7993', '#B82601'), 'Avg Math')

education_df_plus_3 %>% 
  create_hist('mean_science', c(-Inf, 39, 69, 79, 89, Inf), c('#B82601', '#6D7993', '#062F4F', '#6D7993', '#B82601'), 'Avg Science', y.lab = 'County Frequency')

education_df_plus_3 %>% 
  create_hist('mean_literature', c(-Inf, 29, 44, 49, 69, Inf), c('#B82601', '#6D7993', '#062F4F', '#6D7993', '#B82601'), 'Avg Literature')

```
  </div>
<div class="row description">

* <strong><em>Williamson</em></strong> county is showing highest ACT scores, average mathematics, literature, and second highest in science scores.
* The lowest ACT scores are from Lake and Fayette counties
* The lowest mathematics scores are from Cheatham and Putnam counties.
* <strong><em>Fentress</em></strong> takes the lead for the highest science scores at 100%, with Lake being lowest, and <strong><em>Shelby</em></strong> 3rd lowest.
* The lowest literature scores are from Hancock county.

  <p>Ok.. So now we are starting to see a trend. Both Shelby and Williamson County have appeared multiple times in our research. Are there any commonalities?</p>

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warnings=FALSE}
# Subset the education data to only contain the act composite, math, science, and lit cols
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.height=10}

zip_codes_df$income_category <- lapply(zip_codes_df$income_category, function(cat) {

    stackdir='center',

  ) +

    ),

grid.newpage()
grid.draw(
  rbind(ggplotGrob(plot1), ggplotGrob(plot2), ggplotGrob(plot3), size = "last")

```
  </div>
<div class="description">
  <p>Now we get into the interesting stuff.</p>
  <p>We notice that the medium and high income groups rank highest across all three variables. One thing that is consistent about all three is <strong><em>Williamson</em></strong> and <strong><em>Shelby</em></strong>. Shelby is an outlier in each case regarding Dropout and Graduation, whereas Williamson is the outlier in ACT scores, as well as Shelby.</p>
  <p>So what does this tell us?? In general, higher income ranges do not have a huge affect on student education levels compared to the lower. In fact, student that live in counties with a med/high income tend to do better than students within a low or very high income bucket.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="row question-row">
  <blockquote class="blockquote">
    Act Scores Black and Hispanic Populations
  </blockquote>
  
  <div class="col-md-12">
```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
# Melt the df to be indexed by Act compositea
md_demo_act <- melt(demo_act, id=c("ACT_Composite", "county", "income_per_tax_return"))

md_demo_act_shelby_williamson <- md_demo_act %>% 
  dplyr::filter(county == 'williamson' | county == 'shelby')

md_demo_act %>% 
  ggplot(aes(
    x = value,
    y = ACT_Composite,
    color = variable,
    size = income_per_tax_return
  )) + 
  geom_point() +
  geom_point(
    aes(value, ACT_Composite),
    data = md_demo_act_shelby_williamson,
    color = 'blue'
  ) +
  scale_colour_manual(values=c('#B82601', '#062F4F')) +
  geom_smooth(method='lm') + 
  labs(
    title="Avg ACT Scores By Demographics With Size Based on Income Levels",
    y="ACT Score",
    x = "Population Percentage"
  ) +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(
      face = 'bold'
    )
  ) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text(
      face = 'bold'
    )
  )

```
  </div>
<div class="description">
  <p>This graph really helps paint a better picture regarding ACT vs Income, while also incorporating racial demographics as a factor.</p>
  <p>With color relating to race, and size shown by income levels, you can pretty clearly see that there is not a consistent trend regarding income. There are some counties with a high income level doing <em>FANTASTIC</em> on the ACT (such as <strong><em>Williamson</em></strong> at <strong><em>23.8</em></strong>), as well as some mid level counties. Similarly, there are some higher incomes doing <em>POORLY</em> on the ACT.</p>
  <p>However, there does seem to be at least a small, but not insignificant, correlation between the racial population and education levels within counties. As this graph portrays, counties with a higher black population tend to do worse on the ACT vs the hispanic population, with the highest being.. <strong>><em>Shelby</em></strong> at <strong><em>78.4%</em></strong> black population.</p>
</div>
</div>
